contextId.information: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. AT: "he will be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will sit on my throne

contextId.information: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "he will be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he shall sit on my throne

contextId.information: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for being king. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:13|1:13]]. AT: "he will take my place and be king just as I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will sit on my throne in my place

contextId.information: The word "throne" is a metonym for either 1) the person who sits on the throne. AT: "make the one who sits on the throne greater than my master King David" or 2) the kingdom over which the one who sits on the throne rules. AT: "make his kingdom greater than the kingdom of my master King David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: make his throne greater than the throne of my master King David

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) that these words are a metonym for being king. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:01:35|1:35]]. AT: "is now king" or 2) that Solomon was physically sitting on the physical throne. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: is sitting on the throne of the kingdom

contextId.information: The word "throne" is a metonym for the king who sits on the throne. AT: "your descendants will never cease to be kings of Israel" The litotes "will never cease to have" can be stated positively. AT: "one of your descendants will always be the king of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: you will never cease to have a man on the throne of Israel

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "killed those men during a time of peace as if he were killing them in war" or 2) "took revenge on those men during a time of peace because they had killed people in war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: shed the blood of war in peace

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Joab was close enough to these men when he killed them that their blood spattered on his belt and on his sandals or 2) the word "blood" is a metonym for guilt of murder,a nd the belt and the shoes are metonyms for Joab's authority as commander, so David is saying that because Joab is guilty of murder, he should not be commander of the army. Either way, it is best to translate this literally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: put the blood of war on the belt around his waist and on the shoes on his feet

contextId.information: The table is a metonym for the home where the table is. AT: "welcome them to eat at your home" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: let them be among those who eat at your table

contextId.information: Blood is a metonym for violent death, and the head is synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "make sure he dies a violent death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: bring his gray head down to the grave with blood

contextId.information: Turning from the face of someone is a metonym for refusing to look at someone, which in turn is a metonym for refusing to do what that person requests. AT: "do not refuse to do what I request ... he will not refuse to do what you request" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: do not turn away from my face ... he will not turn away from your face

contextId.information: Turning from the face of someone is a metonym for refusing to look at someone, which in turn is a metonym for refusing to do what that person requests. AT: "you will not refuse to do what I request ... I will not refuse to do what you request" Similar words are found in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:02:16|2:16-17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you will not turn away from my face ... I will not turn away from your face

contextId.information: The word "throne" refers to Solomon's authority to rule that was given by Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: set me on the throne

contextId.information: The horns of the altar symbolized Yahweh's power and protection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the horns of the altar

contextId.information: The word "his" refers to Joab. "Blood" is a metonym for murder. And, the idiom "blood return on the head of" means the person should be considered guilty for murder. AT: "Joab has murdered people, and I want Yahweh to hold him guilty for what he has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: May Yahweh return his blood on his own head

contextId.information: The word "blood" is a metonym for murder. And, the idiom "blood return on the head of" means the person should be considered guilty for murder. AT: "I want Yahweh to hold Joab and his descendants guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: may their blood return on the head of Joab and on the head of his descendants

contextId.information: The house is a metonym for the land on which the house stood. The Israelites buried people out of doors in graves or tombs. AT: "where his family lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in his own house

contextId.information: Here "blood" is a metonym for guilt and the head is a metonym for the person. AT: "You will be responsible for your own death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Your blood will be on your own head

contextId.information: Here the head is a metonym for the person, and wickedness is spoken of as if it were a solid or liquid that could be put on a person's head. AT: "will hold you responsible for all your wickedness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will return your wickedness on your own head

contextId.information: Here "throne of David" represents the authority and rule of David and all his descendants forever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the throne of David will be established before Yahweh forever

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for the person, and "for the name" refers to worshiping the person. AT: "in which people would worship Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: The heart is spoken of as if it were a container and compassion as if it were a solid object. AT: "she greatly loved her baby" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: her heart was full of compassion for her son

contextId.information: The words "Judah" and "Israel" are metonyms for the people of Judah and Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah and Israel

contextId.information: The soles of the feet are a metonym for complete control over a person. AT: "Yahweh was enabling David to completely defeat his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh was putting his enemies under the soles of his feet

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for the person. AT: "where Yahweh my God will live ... where I will live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the name of Yahweh my God ... for my name

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon began to build

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon built the temple and finished it

contextId.information: This phrase is a metonym for the walls that enclosed the chambers. AT: "exterior walls that enclosed the inner chambers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: inner chambers

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon ... he built ... he covered ... he covered

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon placed ... Solomon overlaid

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He ... Solomon

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon made ... he made ... he made ... He overlaid ... he spread

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He built the inner court

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon took

contextId.information: Because Solomon was the king, others did the work for him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon took thirteen years to build his own palace

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped the king do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The king had cast them

contextId.information: Solomon would not have done the work himself anyway. AT: "Solomon did not have Huram and his workers weigh all the utensils" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon did not weigh all the utensils

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon made

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the workers finished the work that King Solomon had them do for the house of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the work that King Solomon did for the house of Yahweh was finished

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for the person, and "for ... name" refers to worshiping the person. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "so that people would worship me"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in order for my name to be

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for the person, and "for ... name" refers to worshiping the person. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "in which people would worship Yahweh ... in which people will worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the name of Yahweh ... for my name

contextId.information: The throne is a metonym for the activity of the one who sits on the throne. AT: "to rule over Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to sit on the throne of Israel

contextId.information: The eye is a metonym for what the eye does. AT: "May you watch over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: May your eyes be open toward

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for the person, and "for ... name" refers to worshiping the person. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "in which people will worship you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for your name

contextId.information: Here "throne" refers to his reign. AT: "your dynasty" or "your reign" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the throne of your kingdom

contextId.information: The action of ruling a kingdom is spoken of as if it were a person sitting on a throne. This can be expressed positively. AT: "will always rule over Israel" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: will never fail to be on the throne of Israel

contextId.information: Here the word "name" is a metonym for the person who possesses something. AT: "set apart for myself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: set apart to my name

contextId.information: The person is a metonym for the army he commands. AT: "The army of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had gone up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So Solomon rebuilt Gezer

contextId.information: Solomon is a metonym for the workers he hired to do the work. AT: "So his workers completed the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So he completed the temple

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: King Solomon built

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "Solomon's fame, which glorified Yahweh" or 2) "Solomon's fame, which Yahweh had given him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon's fame concerning the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: The throne is a metonym for the king who sits on it. AT: "who made you king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who placed you on the throne of Israel

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "The king told his people to make" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The king made

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "King Solomon's men made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: King Solomon made

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Solomon do this. AT: "The king's men also made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He also made

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped the king do this. AT: "the king's men made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the king made

contextId.information: The presence of the person is a metonym for being able to speak and listen to the person. AT: "sought an audience with Solomon" or "wanted to visit Solomon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sought the presence of Solomon

contextId.information: The heart is a metonym for what a person thinks and is spoken of as if it were a container. The abstract noun "wisdom" is spoken of as if it were an object that could be put in a container and can be translated as an adjective. It can be a metonym for either the person or the words the person speaks. AT: "to hear his wisdom, which God had given him" or "to hear how wise God had enabled him to be" or "to hear him speak the wise words that God had enabled him to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart

contextId.information: To "turn someone's heart" is to convince that person to change his affection. AT: "persuade you to worship the gods that they worship" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: turn your heart to their gods

contextId.information: The word "hand" refers to authority, power and control. The phrase "lifted up against" refers to having opposed someone by using authority, power and control. This is a metonymy used as a common idiom. AT: "rebelled against the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: lifted up his hand against the king

contextId.information: The word "labor" refers to the work that Solomon commanded the people to do for his government. This is a metonymy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the labor

contextId.information: The name "Solomon" here is a metonym referring to his descendants. AT: "Solomon's sons will have" or "Solomon's descendants will have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Solomon will have

contextId.information: "Eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. This is a commonly used idiom. AT: "what I consider to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: what is right in my eyes

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" is a metonym that refers to a person's authority, control and power. AT: "out of Solomon's control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of Solomon's hand

contextId.information: The word "lamp" is a metonym that refers to a person's influence and guidance. AT: "will always have a descendant to rule as an influence and a guide for obeying my covenant with David's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: may always have a lamp before me

contextId.information: The word "eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. This is a commonly used idiom. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:31|11:33]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: what is right in my eyes

contextId.information: Here "Israel" ​is a metonym for all men of Israel capable of fighting. "All Israel" is an exaggeration which means almost all the men of Israel. AT: "all the men of Israel were coming"​ (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: all Israel was coming

contextId.information: Here "Israel" ​is a metonym for all men of Israel capable of fighting. "All Israel" is an exaggeration which means almost all the men of Israel. AT: "all the men of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: all Israel

contextId.information: "Tents" is a metonym representing a person's place of residence. AT: "Go to your homes, people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Go to your tents, Israel

contextId.information: Here "Israel" is a metonym for the people of Israel. "All Israel" is an exaggeration which means almost all the people of Israel. AT: "all the people of Israel who were there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: all Israel

contextId.information: "Day" is a metonym for a period of time, a duration. Here it refers to the time that the writer was actually writing this. AT: "to the time of the writer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to this day

contextId.information: Here "house" is a metonym that represents a tribe or descendants. And, here "tribe" refers specifically to the soldiers from those tribes. AT: "all the soldiers from the tribes of Judah and Benjamin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin

contextId.information: Here "house" is a metonym that represents a tribe or descendants. AT: "all the people from the tribes of Judah and Benjamin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the house of Judah and Benjamin

contextId.information: "Heart" is a metonym for a person's inner consciousness, thoughts, motivation, or feelings. AT: "thought to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: thought in his heart

contextId.information: "Heart" is a metonym for the people's allegiance and affection. AT: "the allegiance of these people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the heart of these people

contextId.information: "You" here is a metonym for the ancestors of the people. AT: "brought your ancestors up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: brought you up

contextId.information: The workers who did this at Jeroboam's commands are represented by the metonym of the name of Jeroboam himself. AT: "Jeroboam's workers made houses on high places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jeroboam made houses on high places

contextId.information: Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: The word "house" here is a metonymy for "family." AT: "in all of Jeroboam's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of Jeroboam's house

contextId.information: Here "word" represents a message. AT: "the message of Yahweh" or "Yahweh's message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "put his name" is a metonym for "dwell" and refers to the temple where Yahweh was to be worshiped. AT: "in which to dwell" or "in which to be worshiped." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in which to put his name

contextId.information: Here "Judah" represents the people of Judah. AT: "The people of Judah did"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah did

contextId.information: Here the word "nations" represents the people in those nations. AT: "the same disgusting things that the people did, whom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the same despicable practices as the nations that

contextId.information: "Shishak king of Egypt" is a metonym for Shishak along with the Egyptian army. AT: "Shishak king of Egypt, and his army with him, came up against Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "Solomon" refers to the craftsmen who worked for Solomon to make the shields. AT: "that Solomon had his workers make" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: that Solomon had made

contextId.information: Here "King Rehoboam" represents the persons who worked for him to make the shields. AT: "King Rehoboam's workers made shields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: King Rehoboam made shields

contextId.information: Here "hands" represents care or responsibility. AT: "made them the responsibility of the commanders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: entrusted them into the hands of the commanders

contextId.information: The names of the kings means that there was war between the armies of Rehoboam and Jeroboam. AT: "the armies of Rehoboam and Jeroboam fought in battle again and again" (UDB) or "Rehoboam and his people and Jeroboam and his people engaged in battle continually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam

contextId.information: The eyes here represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "what Yahweh judges to be right" or "what Yahweh considers to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was right in his eyes

contextId.information: The word "days" represents a period of time. AT: "the whole time that Abijah lived" or "throughout his whole life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the days of Abijah's life

contextId.information: The names "Abijah" and "Jeroboam" represent the armies of those two kings.  AT: "between the armies of Abijah and Jeroboam" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: between Abijah and Jeroboam

contextId.information: The eyes here represent seeing, and seeing represents judgment. Yahweh saw and approved of Asa's actions. AT: "what Yahweh judges to be right" or "what Yahweh considers to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: Since Asa was king, he may have told his officials to cut down the figure. AT: "Asa caused the disgusting figure to be cut down" or "Asa made them cut down the disgusting figure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Asa cut down the disgusting figure

contextId.information: This refers to the whole period of time that Asa lived. AT: "the whole time that Asa lived" or "throughout Asa'a whole life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all his days

contextId.information: The word "days" represents a period of time, and "all their days" refers to the whole period of time that Asa and Baasha were kings. AT: "the whole time that they reigned over Judah and Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all their days

contextId.information: Putting things in their hands represents giving those things to them. It is implied that they would do with it what he wanted them to do. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "He entrusted it to his servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He put it into the hands of his servants

contextId.information: Breathing represents being alive. AT: "He left none of Jeroboam's descendants living" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He left none of Jeroboam's descendants breathing

contextId.information: The word "days" represents a period of time, and "all their days" refers to the whole period of time that Asa and Baasha were kings. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:16|15:16]] AT: "the whole time that they reigned over Judah and Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all their days

contextId.information: The word "chariots" here represents the soldiers who drove the chariots. AT: "captain of half his chariot drivers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: captain of half his chariots

contextId.information: The word "He" refers to Omri. He commanded people to build the city. AT: "Omri had his people build a city" or "Omri commanded and his workers built a city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He built a city

contextId.information: Here the word "word" represents a message. AT: "the message of  Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Speaking "by" someone represents both telling someone to speak and the person doing it. AT: "which Yahweh caused Joshua son of Nun to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: which he spoke by Joshua son of Nun

contextId.information: Here "the word" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "as Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: as the word of Yahweh commanded

contextId.information: Here "word" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "just as Yahweh had said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: just as the word of Yahweh had said

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents what Elijah prayed. AT: "Yahweh answered Elijah's prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh listened to the voice of Elijah

contextId.information: Here "word" represents a message. Also, "mouth" represents what Elijah said. AT: "the message that you spoke from Yahweh is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh in your mouth is true

contextId.information: "Word" is metonymy for what a person says. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.information: The phrase "by himself" emphasizes that Ahab and Obadiah went in separate directions, not necessarily that no one was with Ahab. AT: "Ahab lead a team in one direction and Obadiah lead a team in the other direction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Ahab went one way by himself and Obadiah went another way

contextId.information: "Name" is metonymy for the reputation and honor of someone and "calling on" him represents an appeal. AT: "call to your god ... call to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: call on the name of your god ... call on the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: "turn their heart" is a metonymy for the affection and loyalty of the people. AT: "caused them to be loyal to you again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: turned their heart back again to yourself

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" is a metonymy for strength. AT: "Yahweh gave his power to Elijah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of Yahweh was on Elijah

contextId.information: "Sword" is metonymy for for killing as in battle. AT: "whomever Hazael does not kill with the sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: whoever escapes from the sword of Hazael

contextId.information: "Bending down" and "kissing" are metonymies for actions people did to worship idols. They are combined for emphasis. AT: "who have not bowed down and kissed Baal" or "who have not worshiped Baal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: whose knees have not bent down to Baal, and whose mouths have not kissed him

contextId.information: "Pleasing their eyes" is metonymy for looking at something and desiring it. AT: "whatever pleases them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: whatever pleases their eyes

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "give you victory over that army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: place it into your hand

contextId.information: "Yourself" represents by metonymy the army of the king. AT: "strengthen your forces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: strengthen yourself

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "give you victory over this great army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: place this great army into your hand

contextId.information: "Sign" is metonymy for an action that gives a meaning. AT: "for any action from Ahab that would show them that Ahab wanted to be merciful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for any sign from Ahab

contextId.information: "the word" is metonymy for the message. AT: "as Yahweh had told him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: by the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" is metonymy for power. AT: "released" or "spared the life of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: let go from your hand

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) she wrote Ahab's name on the letters. AT: "wrote letters and signed them with Ahab's name" or 2) the word "name" is a metonym for authority. AT: "wrote letters on behalf of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: wrote letters in Ahab's name

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "for the Lord will allow the king to capture Ramoth Gilead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the Lord will give it into the hand of the king

contextId.information: Here "all Israel" refers to the army of Israel. AT: "I saw the entire army of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: I saw all Israel

contextId.information: Here the word "spirit" refers to the attitudes of the prophets and the words "the mouth" represents what they will say. AT: "cause all his prophets to speak lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets

contextId.information: Here the word "spirit" refers to the attitudes of the prophets and the words "the mouth" represents what they will say. AT: "has caused all of your prophets to speak lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: has put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these prophets of yours

contextId.information: Here "the word of Yahweh" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "just as Yahweh had declared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: just as the word of Yahweh had declared
